linkTarget.anchoringText: The flowchart for the deterministic approach is presented in Figure 1. One single history match is obtained per selected model. The approach often lingers over the definition of a Base Case model which most of the time is the P50 model, and the other realizations are used to capture the high and low ends.

The schematic flowchart is illustrated in Figure 2. In a case where the uncertainites in the static volumes is less than a defined threshold value, the simplified probabilistic approach can be used which only considers one history match dynamic model per static model and in that sense becomes the same as the deterministic approach of Figure 1 which only considers the static uncertainties in the volume in place estimation.

A suitable work-around could be the selection of three representative geological models using a Geo-screening approach (Brownless and Steele 2013). This will ensure that the hydrocarbon in-place and connected volume are correlated properly, see Figure 3.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: selecting P90, P50 and P10 static models using Geo-screening

formatted-caption.caption-text: selecting P90, P50 and P10 static models using Geo-screening

linkTarget.anchoringText: A general probabilistic modeling workflow has been suggested by R. Abd Karim and R.D. Tewari (2017) as shown in Figure 4. This workflow can be used for an appropriate probabilistic modeling exercise. In this section, however, a number of common misuses of probabilistic forecasting workflow is addressed and some case studies are discussed:

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: probabilistic dynamic modeling workflow (after R. Abd Karim and R.D. Tewari, 2017)

formatted-caption.caption-text: probabilistic dynamic modeling workflow (after R. Abd Karim and R.D. Tewari, 2017)

linkTarget.anchoringText: To consider multiple parameters which could have similar effects on the mismatch parameter. An example is shown in Figure 8 in which multiple uncertain paramteres have same effect on matching the reservoir pressure.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The case studies shown in this study indicated that improper use of probabilistic forecasting approach, or lack of enough data and understanding of the reservoir to properly frame uncertainties could make the whole exercise fruitless and all the effort to go in vain. The effects of bias and the proper criteria of selecting the Base Case for development sanction has to be considered (Figure 12)
